definitions.definition: A change of direction of motion after hitting the ground or an obstacle.
A movement up and then down (or vice versa), once or repeatedly.
An email return with any error.
The sack, licensing.
A bang, boom.
A drink based on brandyW.
A heavy, sudden, and often noisy, blow or thump.
Bluster; brag; untruthful boasting; audacious exaggeration; an impudent lie; a bouncer.
Scyliorhinus canicula, a European dogfish.
A genre of New Orleans music.
Drugs.
Swagger.
A 'good' beat.
A talent for leaping.
To change the direction of motion after hitting an obstacle.
definitions.example: The tennis ball bounced off the wall before coming to rest in the ditch.

definitions.definition: To move quickly up and then down, or vice versa, once or repeatedly.
definitions.example: He bounces nervously on his chair.

definitions.definition: To cause to move quickly up and down, or back and forth, once or repeatedly.
definitions.example: He bounced the child on his knee.

definitions.definition: To suggest or introduce (an idea, etc.) to (off or by) somebody, in order to gain feedback.
definitions.example: I'm meeting Bob later to bounce some ideas off him about the new product range.

definitions.definition: To leap or spring suddenly or unceremoniously; to bound.
definitions.example: She bounced happily into the room.

definitions.definition: To move rapidly (between).
(of a cheque/check) To be refused by a bank because it is drawn on insufficient funds.
definitions.example: We can’t accept further checks from you, as your last one bounced.

definitions.definition: To fail to cover (have sufficient funds for) (a draft presented against one's account).
definitions.example: He tends to bounce a check or two toward the end of each month, before his payday.

definitions.definition: To leave.
definitions.example: Let’s wrap this up, I gotta bounce.

definitions.definition: To eject violently, as from a room; to discharge unceremoniously, as from employment.
(sometimes employing the preposition with) To have sexual intercourse.
(air combat) To attack unexpectedly.
definitions.example: The squadron was bounced north of the town.

definitions.definition: To turn power off and back on; to reset
definitions.example: See if it helps to bounce the router.

definitions.definition: (of an e-mail message or address) To return undelivered.
definitions.example: The girl in the bar told me her address was thirsty@example.com, but my mail to that address bounced back to me.

definitions.definition: To land hard and lift off again due to excess momentum.
definitions.example: The student pilot bounced several times during his landing.

definitions.definition: (skydiving) To land hard at unsurvivable velocity with fatal results.
definitions.example: After the mid-air collision, his rig failed and he bounced. BSBD.

definitions.definition: (sound recording) To mix (two or more tracks of a multi-track audio tape recording) and record the result onto a single track, in order to free up tracks for further material to be added.
definitions.example: Bounce tracks two and three to track four, then record the cowbell on track two.

definitions.definition: To bully; to scold.
To strike or thump, so as to rebound, or to make a sudden noise; to knock loudly.
To boast; to bluster.
